items.title: Jimmy Kimmel show to return after ABC pulled it over Charlie Kirk comments
Disney says Jimmy Kimmel will return to air on Tuesday
items.standfirst: Kimmel was suspended last week for comments he made about the death of Charlie Kirk.
items.content: Disney announced “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” will resume airing on Tuesday, ending Kimmel's short-lived suspension following comments the host made on his show about the killing of Charlie Kirk. In a statement released Monday, Disney said it suspended Kimmel last week “to avoid inflaming a tense situation.” The company received intense pressure from Trump allies, including Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr, over Kimmel’s comments. “Last Wednesday, we made the decision to suspend production on the show to avoid further inflaming a tense situation at an emotional moment for our country,” Disney said in the statement. “It is a decision we made because we felt some of the comments were ill-timed and thus insensitive.” “We have spent the last days having thoughtful conversations with Jimmy, and after those conversations, we reached the decision to return the show on Tuesday,” the statement continued. Kimmel’s suspension set off a wave of criticism from leaders in both parties who were concerned about political censorship. Prior to Kimmel’s suspension, Carr condemned Kimmel’s comments and suggested that media companies who receive licensing from the FCC have “an obligation to operate in the public interest.” “We can do this the easy way or the hard way,” Carr said last Wednesday in an interview. Hours later on Wednesday, Nexstar Media Group and Sinclair Broadcasting Group, two of the nation’s largest owners of local television stations, said they would preempt tapings of “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” because of Kimmel’s comments. Nexstar Media Group is currently pursuing a billion-dollar merger with Tegna that would require FCC approval. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment. A handful of prominent Republicans on Capitol Hill, including Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, warned that Carr could set a dangerous precedent and urged the Trump administration to be careful in pressuring a private company to influence its speech. Democratic leaders in Washington and hundreds of artists and celebrities joined in condemning Kimmel’s suspension. FCC commissioner Anna Gomez, the lone Democrat in the agency's leadership, welcomed Kimmel's return to air and praised Americans who criticized the suspension. "I am glad to see Disney find its courage in the face of clear government intimidation," she said. Andrew Kolvet, a spokesperson for Turning Point USA, encouraged Nexstar and Sinclair to keep their pledge to preempt Kimmel when his show returns. “Disney and ABC caving and allowing Kimmell back on the air is not surprising, but it's their mistake to make,” Kolvet said in a social media post Monday. “Nextstar and Sinclair do not have to make the same choice.”

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel returning to air Tuesday
items.standfirst: ABC announced Monday that "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" will return to the air Tuesday night. The network pulled the show last week following a remark from Kimmel about the death of Charlie Kirk.
items.content: ABC announced Monday that "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" will return to the air Tuesday night. The network pulled the show last week following a remark from Kimmel about the death of Charlie Kirk.

ai_summary: Disney announced Jimmy Kimmel Live! will return to air on Tuesday, ending a suspension.
The suspension followed controversial remarks made by Kimmel about Charlie Kirk's death.
Some sources report the suspension was due to Kimmel's comments on the Charlie Kirk shooting.
The FCC chair received criticism for potentially pressuring channels to remove Kimmel.
Media reporter Scott Nover will discuss the situation on "The Takeout" on CBS News.

items.title: France recognises Palestine and calls for UN force in Gaza
items.standfirst: Macron sets out plan for international stabilisation mission as Arab and Muslim leaders prepare to meet Trump in New YorkEmmanuel Macron has announced France’s official recognition of the State of Palestine, setting out a plan for a UN-mandated international stabilisation force in postwar Gaza that is expected to find support in many countries but not in Israel or the US.“The time has come to end the war in Gaza, the massacres and the death,” Macron said during a speech opening a special summit in the United Nations general assembly hall on Monday evening. “The time has come to do justice for the Palestinian people and thus to recognise the State of Palestine in Gaza, the West Bank and Jerusalem.” Continue reading...

items.title: Mounting cost of war on both Palestinians and Israel
items.standfirst: France has joined several of its European peers in formally recognising a Palestinian State. At a world summit in New York on Monday, President Emmanuel Macron called on the world to do everything it could to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution and outlined a framework for a "renewed Palestinian Authority". Nearly two years since it began the war has devastated the livelihoods of Palestinian people but also dealt a serious blow to Israel's economy.
items.content: France has joined several of its European peers in formally recognising a Palestinian State. At a world summit in New York on Monday, President Emmanuel Macron called on the world to do everything it could to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution and outlined a framework for a "renewed Palestinian Authority". Nearly two years since it began the war has devastated the livelihoods of Palestinian people but also dealt a serious blow to Israel's economy.

items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday recognised a Palestinian state at a UN summit aimed at galvanising support for a two-state solution to the Mideast conflict a day ahead of the 2025 UN General Assembly in New York. Macron has spearheaded a move that spurred other Western governments to take the landmark step that has infuriated Israel.

items.title: Italy cautious on Palestinian recognition as protests grow
items.standfirst: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.
items.content: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.

items.title: Disruption across Italy as tens of thousands protest against Gaza war
items.standfirst: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensiveTens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in dozens of cities across Italy – shutting schools, disrupting trains and blocking ports and roads – in one of Europe’s largest nationwide protests against Israel’s offensive in Gaza.The protests came as France and several other countries prepared to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UN general assembly on Monday after the UK, Australia, Portugal and Canada did so on Sunday. Continue reading...

clusters.title: As Trump makes autism announcement, Tylenol maker and medical experts push back
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Urges Pregnant Women to Limit Tylenol Use

items.title: As Trump makes autism announcement, Tylenol maker and medical experts push back
items.standfirst: The Trump administration announced it believes acetaminophen is linked to autism risk, but the maker of Tylenol and medical experts have strongly pushed back on the claims.
items.content: The Trump administration announced it believes acetaminophen is linked to autism risk, but the maker of Tylenol and medical experts have strongly pushed back on the claims.

items.title: Trump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autism
items.standfirst: President says acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol - increases risk when taken by pregnant women, assertion contradicted by researchThe Trump administration unveiled highly contentious conclusions about the causes of autism, together with a push for research purporting to find a possible “cure” for the condition on Monday.After months of widely trumpeted investigations spearheaded by the health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, Donald Trump announced that pregnant women should limit their use of acetaminophen, usually branded as Tylenol in the US or paracetamol elsewhere, which he claimed heightens the risk of autism when it used by pregnant women, an assertion hotly contested by scientists internationally and contradicted by studies. Continue reading...
items.content: President says acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol - increases risk when taken by pregnant women, assertion contradicted by researchThe Trump administration unveiled highly contentious conclusions about the causes of autism, together with a push for research purporting to find a possible “cure” for the condition on Monday.After months of widely trumpeted investigations spearheaded by the health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, Donald Trump announced that pregnant women should limit their use of acetaminophen, usually branded as Tylenol in the US or paracetamol elsewhere, which he claimed heightens the risk of autism when it used by pregnant women, an assertion hotly contested by scientists internationally and contradicted by studies. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump urges pregnant women to avoid Tylenol over unproven autism link
items.standfirst: Some studies have suggested an association between the two, but experts say there is no causal relationship.
items.content: Some studies have suggested an association between the two, but experts say there is no causal relationship.

items.title: Breaking down Trump's claims about Tylenol and autism
items.standfirst: President Trump announced on Monday that the FDA believes the use of acetaminophen -- the active ingredient in Tylenol and many cold and flu medications -- during pregnancy can be associated with an increased risk of autism, though medical experts have said the medication is safe. CBS News White House reporter Olivia Rinaldi has the details. Then, Dr. Steven Fleischman, president of the American College of Obstetricians, joins with his reaction to the news.
items.content: President Trump announced on Monday that the FDA believes the use of acetaminophen -- the active ingredient in Tylenol and many cold and flu medications -- during pregnancy can be associated with an increased risk of autism, though medical experts have said the medication is safe. CBS News White House reporter Olivia Rinaldi has the details. Then, Dr. Steven Fleischman, president of the American College of Obstetricians, joins with his reaction to the news.

items.title: Supreme Court lets Trump remove FTC’s Rebecca Slaughter, for now
items.standfirst: The U.S. Supreme Court sided again on Monday with Donald Trump, allowing the Republican president to fire a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission—for now—despite Congress providing job protections for this post. The court blocked an order by Washington-based U.S. District Judge Loren…
items.content: The U.S. Supreme Court sided again on Monday with Donald Trump, allowing the Republican president to fire a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission—for now—despite Congress providing job protections for this post. The court blocked an order by Washington-based U.S. District Judge Loren…

items.title: Supreme court lets Trump fire FTC commissioner for now and will hear arguments later
items.standfirst: Court grants justice department request to block judge’s order that shielded Rebecca Slaughter from being dismissedThe US supreme court on Monday let Donald Trump fire a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission, for now, while agreeing to hear arguments in the case in December, setting up a major test of presidential power over government agencies designed by Congress to be independent.The court granted a justice department request to block a judge’s order that had shielded Rebecca Slaughter, who sued to challenge Trump’s action, from being dismissed from the consumer protection and antitrust agency before her term expires in 2029. Continue reading...
items.content: Court grants justice department request to block judge’s order that shielded Rebecca Slaughter from being dismissedThe US supreme court on Monday let Donald Trump fire a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission, for now, while agreeing to hear arguments in the case in December, setting up a major test of presidential power over government agencies designed by Congress to be independent.The court granted a justice department request to block a judge’s order that had shielded Rebecca Slaughter, who sued to challenge Trump’s action, from being dismissed from the consumer protection and antitrust agency before her term expires in 2029. Continue reading...

items.title: France: Trial begins for Cédric Jubillar over wife’s disappearance
items.standfirst: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.
items.content: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.

items.title: France transfixed by murder trial without a body
items.standfirst: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.
items.content: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.

ai_summary: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France.
He is accused of murdering his wife, Delphine.
Delphine disappeared in December 2020.
Her body has never been found.
Evidence includes alleged threats and phone records.

clusters.title: British couple held by Taliban for months feared they would be executed
clusters.neutral_headline: British couple held by Taliban for months feared they would be executed

items.title: British couple held by Taliban for months feared they would be executed
items.standfirst: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, 80 and 76, said it was never explained to them why they were being held.
items.content: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, 80 and 76, said it was never explained to them why they were being held.

items.title: British couple released after detention in Afghanistan say they feared being executed
items.standfirst: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisonedA British couple who were reunited with their family in the UK after being released from almost eight months in detention in Afghanistan have said they feared being executed by the Taliban.Peter Reynolds, 80, and his wife, Barbie, 76, who arrived at Heathrow on Saturday, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisoned in Afghanistan after their arrest in February. Continue reading...
items.content: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisonedA British couple who were reunited with their family in the UK after being released from almost eight months in detention in Afghanistan have said they feared being executed by the Taliban.Peter Reynolds, 80, and his wife, Barbie, 76, who arrived at Heathrow on Saturday, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisoned in Afghanistan after their arrest in February. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Peter and Barbie Reynolds were held in Afghanistan.
They were held for almost eight months.
They said they feared being executed by the Taliban.
They were never told why they were imprisoned.
The couple was reunited with their family in the UK.
